theme.title: The 4/4 time signature
theme.para: In this lesson we will learn about the 4/4 time signature. As you know the top number tells how many beats are there in a measure, and the bottom number shows the type of note that gets one beat ('4' means 'quarter note'). Therefore, the 4/4 time signature is a rhythm with four beats per measure and each measure gets four quarter notes.

The accents on this rhythm follows the pattern Strong-Weak-Medium-Weak, that is, the first beat of a measure is always the strongest one, and the three other beats are weaker, being the third one a little stronger.

If you count beats along with the music, the 4/4 time signature will imply a rhythm such as 'ONE-two-three-four-and-ONE-two-three-four-and- ...', stressing the ONE syllable and a little less the 'three' syllable.
This rhythm is widely used in classical music; also it is the usual time signature in rock, jazz, and modern pop and dance music.

part.title: The whole note and its rest
part.para: In this lesson we are going also to learn a new note symbol and its rest: the whole note. The following score shows a whole note and a whole rest:

part.para: One whole note equals two half notes and one whole rest equals two half rests. So in time 4/4 a whole note or rest gets four beats, and, therefore, takes a whole measure. Two tied half notes equals a whole note:
